newsitem.title: USA: Californians urged to back 'No Budget, No Pay'bill.
newsitem.headline: Californians urged to back 'No Budget, No Pay'bill.

text.p: A California legislator on Friday appealed to the public to support a bill requiring state lawmakers to give up their pay if they are late enacting the state's budget.
State Assemblyman Jim Morrissey, a Republican, urged Californians write or call their local legislators to support Assembly Constitutional Amendment 2, dubbed the "No Budget, No Pay!" bill.

The measure would require the governor and legislators to forfeit their pay for each day that they are late enacting the state budget. Legislators would also forfeit the $105 per diem they receive for daily expenses.
"'No Budget, No Pay!' would provide a strong incentive to all members to finish the budget on time," Morrissey said.

The legislature is required to approve the state budget no later than June 15, and it must be signed by the governor no later than June 30. But the governor and the legislature have regularly failed to meet the July 1 deadline.
In 1992, the budget was more than two months late.
Morrissey introduced his "No Budget, No Pay!" bill in January, but lawmakers have yet to set a hearing date for the measure. A similar bill failed last year.
